transcripts.text: To be honest with you, I planned a lot of things in life that don't come out the way I want them to.  But my wedding came out exactly as I dreamt about it.  So, it was one perfect day for me.

Welcome to a new edition of One Plus Two.  One Plus Two is a series that we do where we interview very interesting people.  We ask them rapid-fire questions the first minute, and in the second minute they can expatiate on the answers they give in the first minute.  Today, it is my special privilege and honor To introduce to you, José Carmelion.  José Carmelion is one of the best.  most entertaining and most illustrious singers and performer in Africa.  He has collaborated with everybody from all over Africa, ranging from David Doe, artists from Jamaica, like Benny Mann.  Welcome, Mr.  Kamelion.  We're going to ask you rapid-fire questions for one minute.  You've not seen the questions?  You don't know what questions we're going to ask?  If there is one question you cannot answer or you think, like, maybe it's too controversial, you have... One, you can just say pass and then we'll pass on that one.  Before we start, is there something you would just like to say to the people who are watching this?

Yeah, I'm very honored to be on this platform.  I'm very honored to be right here with African Web TV, right in Netherlands, to be addressing and talking to my people, my fans, and those that know me and those that don't know me.  Anyway, however, it's going to be a great evening, so ready to start.  I won't pass for now.  We shall begin.
Best song you have ever written?
I should say Mamma Mia.
The best artist you have ever collaborated with?
Professor Jay Tanzania.
Ugali or Matoke?
Ugali.
East African music or West African music?
East African music.
The biggest regret in life?
Um...
best moments of your life so far my wedding.  performing in africa performing outside africa outside africa.  which artist would you like to work with?  um?  Answer the question.
Yeah, I've worked with the Jamaican.
Why do you sing mostly Swahili?
Because I'm trying to trade my culture and language outside my region.
Fame or fortune?
Fortune.  Grammy or Afrima?  Grammy.
How was the one minute?
It was quite short, even too fast.
Was there a question we asked that you thought like, hey, you have not been asked this question before?
The worst regret?  Anything I regret?  That's a question that I've not approached before.  And definitely everybody has something to regret, but there's so many of them.
Which is the best song you have ever written?
Mamma Mia.
That's what you said, Mamma Mia.  Mamma Mia, you wrote Mamma Mia in... 1999.  1999.  Yes.  And why is that song special?

It is special because it broke the ice.  I mean, a lot of artists underground tried to struggle to become, and then what they lack is a song to start their career.  So for me, Mamma Mia remains very important because it introduced me to the world.
But I understand that Bagea was the first hit you got.
Yeah, Bagea was the first hit.  Oh, that sounds... Bagea, yeah, it was the first hit, but it was a national hit.  Mamma Mia was an international hit.  Yeah.
And... You like West African music less than East African music?

Yeah, definitely, because I'm an ambassador to who I am.  So, I mean, and they say charity begins at home.  I'm not trying to say that West African music is not good music.  It is good music, but it's mandated to be selling my culture to West Africa.  Like West Africa is mandated to be selling their music to me.  So mine comes first.  Yeah.
And which artist would you like to work with?  You said Bujibanton?  Bujibanton, yeah.

Why?  Because he inspired me since I was a child.  I mean, I still adore him.  I still admire him.  And I've not yet worked with him until I work with him.  That's why I really want to work with him because he inspired me from root level.
Okay.  And the question was, why do you think mostly Swahili?
Yeah, because I'm trying to tread my culture.  Like I told you, Swahili is a very beautiful language that is used in the East African region that I need to spread out to the world.
And you prefer to get a Grammy to Afrima?
Yeah, because the Grammy is the pinnacle of the career.  I mean, I already have an Afrima.  So what don't I have is the Grammy.  It's the pinnacle.  That's like the finishing point.
Yes.  And the best day of your life?  You said it was your wedding.
My wedding.
We ran out of time, but I think our viewers got that, that your wedding was the best year of your life.  We're going to cheat a bit.  Will you tell us a bit about your wedding?

Yeah, my wedding was an anticipation.  You know, finding the love of your life takes a big search, especially for us men.  Maybe you're different, but for me, it took me quite a while to choose who to get married to.  i anticipated and um to be honest with you i planned a lot of things in life that don't come out the way i want them to but my wedding came out exactly as i dreamt about it so it was one perfect day for me.
